Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Physics and Astrophysics of Compact Binaries
Award.AbstractNarration:
This CAREER award supports research at the University of Mississippi on the physics and astrophysics of double star systems containing only black holes and/or neutrons stars (compact binaries). These systems are among the most promising sources of gravitational waves to be detected by present and future gravitational-wave observatories, such as LIGO and and the space-based LISA. One of the main challenges in gravitational-wave data analysis consists in extracting the signal emitted by the system from the noisy detector output. For the extraction to be successful, accurate theoretical "template" waveforms of the signal are needed. This research will improve theoretical knowledge of gravitational waveforms from merging compact binaries using a combination of analytical techniques (such as the so-called post-Newtonian approximation and black hole perturbation theory) and numerical simulations.

The project will explore the potential of future gravitational-wave observations to test the predictions of general relativity, as opposed to alternative theories of gravity. It will also "put more astronomy in gravitational-wave astronomy" by investigating the astrophysical implications of gravitational-wave observations, and by stimulating interactions between the general relativity community and the larger astrophysical community. The award will partially support the training of one student and one postdoc in the highly interdisciplinary field between general relativity, astrophysics and data analysis. It will also support a long-term outreach program to promote scientific literacy and increase enrollment in the physical sciences in Mississippi. Outreach activities will target in particular historically black colleges and universities, as well as universities and community colleges in the Mississippi Delta.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the duration of this award, the PI and his group made significant advances in our understanding of compact binaries, astrophysical tests of general relativity and gravitational-wave astronomy. The main findings include: (1) the prediction that binary black holes would dominate LIGO detection rates, made well before the LIGO detection of a binary black hole merger (GW150914) by combining state-of-the-art waveform models and astrophysical population synthesis codes; (2) a deeper understanding of the dynamics of spinning, precessing black hole binaries in terms of an "effective potential" approach, which led to the discovery of a new instability in spinning black hole binary systems; (3) theoretical progress in understanding black holes and neutron stars in modified theories of gravity, and the writing of a comprehensive review on astrophysical tests of general relativity in the regime where gravity is strong; (4) progress in the study of black hole collisions close to the speed of light; and (5) progress in developing the theory of black hole perturbations and instabilities, in particular the implications of "superradiance" (the extraction of energy from astrophysical rotating black holes) for particle physics.

In total, over the 5 years this CAREER award provided partial financial support for 5 postdoctoral researchers and 3 graduate students at the University of Mississippi. Two of these postdocs now hold faculty jobs, and one of the students received a graduate achievement award from the University. Students and postdocs were trained in cutting edge scientific research and involved in international collaborations through two research networks (IRSES and RISE) funded by the European Union. They learned how to disseminate results through publications and conference presentations, and they were encouraged to become independent researchers, producing several publications where the PI was not a co-author. The PI prepared lecture notes on black holes for various advanced schools, and wrote a "Physics Viewpoint" article (commissioned by the Editors of Physical Review Letters) to accompany the historic article that announced the first detection of gravitational waves. He was the main organizer of three workshops at the University of Mississippi, and he lectured on black holes and gravitational waves at five HBCUs and Community Colleges in Mississippi (Alcorn State University, Mississippi Delta Community College, Rust College, Jackson State University and Tougaloo College). In an effort to promote STEM education and physics enrollment in Mississippi, students from these Colleges visited the campus of the University of Mississippi and the LIGO detector in Louisiana.
